importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the most current context of the ongoing discussion about Tomahawk missile deployment to Ukraine.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame from late August to mid-October 2025, during which Trump engaged in talks with both Putin and Zelensky, and the possibility of sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine has been under discussion.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump did not rule out sending Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine during a call with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Trump is not expected to commit to providing Tomahawk missiles in a meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, though the possibility remains open.
The US administration has developed plans to provide the weapons if Trump decides to deploy them, which he can do at any time.
Zelensky and his aides view Tomahawk missiles as a potential game-changer that could pressure Putin to negotiate a peace deal.
Putin opposed the idea, arguing that such missiles would damage the US-Russian relationship and could lead to escalation, despite their long range.
Trump emphasized the threat of sending missiles to Ukraine during the call with Putin, saying: 'Would you mind if I gave a couple thousand Tomahawks to your opposition?'
Trump's administration is using the threat of missile deployment as a diplomatic tool to push for a peace agreement, rather than an immediate military escalation.
The possibility of a meeting between Trump and Putin in Budapest was discussed after a call, which may have delayed a resolution but reinforced diplomatic efforts.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former President of the United States and current political figure involved in the discussion of military aid to Ukraine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is the central figure in the article, as he has not ruled out sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine and has publicly discussed the idea during conversations with Putin and Zelensky.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of Russia and key opposing figure in diplomatic negotiations with Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin opposed the idea of Tomahawk missiles being sent to Ukraine, fearing escalation and damage to the US-Russia relationship, and engaged in a direct phone call with Trump to counter the proposal.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: President of Ukraine and a key recipient of the proposed Tomahawk missile deployment
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky and his aides have described the Tomahawk missiles as a potential game-changer in the war, and they view the threat of receiving them as a tool to pressure Putin into negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk cruise missiles
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Long-range American-made cruise missiles with a range exceeding 1,000 miles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The missiles are a focal point of diplomatic tension between the US and Russia, with both sides interpreting their deployment as a significant strategic or escalatory move.

namedEntities.name: Ukraine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A nation at war with Russia, seeking military support from the US
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ukraine is the potential recipient of the Tomahawk missiles, which are seen as a possible turning point in the war and a bargaining chip in peace negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Russia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The nation at war with Ukraine, opposing the deployment of Tomahawk missiles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Russia views the missile deployment as a threat to its national security and a sign of increased US military involvement in the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Hungary where a meeting between Trump and Putin was proposed
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The proposed meeting in Budapest was a result of Putin's efforts to delay or prevent the missile deployment, and it reflects the diplomatic maneuvering between the US and Russia.

namedEntities.name: Middle East negotiations
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US diplomatic efforts involving other international actors
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump’s growing interest in diplomatic peace efforts, including in the Middle East, is cited as a context that may influence his approach to the Ukraine conflict.

summaryOfNewsArticle: During a recent call with Russian President Vladimir Putin, President Donald Trump did not rule out sending long-range Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine, despite Putin’s opposition. Trump expressed the idea of supplying the missiles to Ukraine’s opposition as a tool of leverage, which could pressure Putin to negotiate. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has long viewed the weapons as a potential game-changer in the war, hoping they would force a peace settlement. However, the US administration has not committed to the deployment, and officials note that Trump can reverse the decision at any time. Putin argued that such a move would damage US-Russian relations and threaten major Russian cities, while US officials see the threat as a strategic diplomatic tool rather than an immediate escalation. A proposed meeting in Budapest between Trump and Putin may have delayed a resolution, but the broader context of US diplomatic success in the Middle East underscores Trump’s focus on peace through negotiation.
title: Trump hasn’t closed the door on sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine
